doc/source/development_guidelines.rst.message: I think it is OK to more opinionated i.e. delete "(Optional but recommended)" - the docs should describe a recommended approach.

I'd prefer to instruct devs to use the tox environments to build a virtualenv. It's less typing, will install requirements using the appropriate constraints for the python version, and gives the exact same test environment as CI. i.e.:

  tox -e py38 devenv
  source ./foo/bin/activate
  pytest test/unit/common/middleware/crypto
  
(I don't have py3.6 installed so use py38 as an example)

this is not an "or" with respect to the example "run only the pep8 checks and python2.7 unit tests"

However, it would be appropriate to just replace all the references to py27 with py3 in these examples.

ansible/network.yml.message: at first glance, this doesn't give a clear idea what's being looped over.
this loops over all the active interfaces in the system with ipv4 address set.

I figured as much. What I mean is that when you look at the statement, it's not clear enough what it's doing. You're taking ALL of `ansible_facts`, flattening it with `dict2items` and picking out whatever datastructure has `value.ipv4.address`, possibly including iscsi block devices. It would be better if there were rewritten with some "precision" to the query, to make it clearer what you're specifically looking for.

Something like;

 loop: "{{ interfaces_with_ipv4_address }}"
 vars:
   # renaming br-whatever to br_whatever to find them in the ansible_facts
   interface_facts: "{{ ansible_facts.interfaces | map('regex_replace', '-', '_') | map('extract', ansible_facts) }}"
   interfaces_with_ipv4_address: "{{ interface_facts | selectattr('ipv4.address', 'defined') }}"
`rescue` just feels wrong. Better to have when clause to each for os_family, or better yet move them into network-{{ os_family }} that's happening the line below.

It's a bit concering seeing failed tasks in the output. What should happen if there's some mis-configuration leading to the task actually failing on RedHat systems, and it tries the rescue section for this other platform?

You could probably still resolve this into a single task with a lookup to a vars section.

 vars:
   some_lookup_for_os_family:
     Debian:
       key: item.value[0].Match.blabla.Name
       value: item.value[1].blabla.Address
     RedHat:
       key: item.device
       value: item.address ~ item.netmask

But the `| dict2items` and looking at `value[0]` or `value[1]` is a bit of a mess, and would be better rewritten some other way.

Is the structure in `network_interfaces` that different between redhat and debian systems?

don't agree, we have only two family, so this code is more clean and compact in comparison to the method you propose. each task have the correct name and executed in the correct way. please read the official article how to handle errors in the blocks: https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/playbook_guide/playbooks_blocks.html#handling-errors-with-blocks

ansible/roles/network-debian/tasks/main..message: restarting the service for every interface in interfaces_cleanup? Can't this all be handled in one swoop?

     ip link delete {{ item }} || ip address delete ...

We're restarting only once, and deleting all interfaces after the fact.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: I think we should switch to curl-minimal for all redhat family from 9 onwards

I'm in agreement with @sbaker - we should move to minimal for c9s+.

If users want/need the full curl, they can `dnf swap curl-minimal curl`. I had a local branch I hadn't yet sent for review which does this in the containerfile, which is another option, but I still prefer just keeping minimal.
do we need this also for centos stream 9 ? seems like tripleo had similar issue - https://bugs.launchpad.net/tripleo/+bug/1953156
kayobe-seed-images-rocky9 (non-voting) will be fixed with https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/diskimage-builder/+/869424

AFAICS we basically don't have any sane way to say "curl|curl-minimal" (we could do something like have a dummy cache-url package that depends on curl, that seems like it would be satisifed if either was installed, but that's not "sane" 😊 ).

Whatever choice we make seems like it could be wrong.  I'm almost of the opinion that we can't solve this with package-installs/pkg-map.  

I feel like it would be OK to drop this and assume that the base system comes with curl -- replace it with a note in README that curl is required and probably a if [[ ! -f /usr/bin/curl ]]; then "something useful"; fi type message ...
sorry wrong window :)
I'm open to ideas, but i think the best move is not to play -- I9ccebe2dbf3a8682dab60c2070c5f78849e01446

in the RHEL world we can say e.g. `dnf install /usr/bin/curl` or have a `requires` against that, for which both curl and curl-minimal fulfill.

It seems for rocky, the cache-url element is what is requiring curl, so I suppose we could also conditionalize it there somehow?

rockylinux 9, centos stream 9 and probably rhel 9 ubi images come with curl-minimal, id order to install curl, we would need to uninstall curl-minimal.
I don't have an opinion if we should stick to curl-minimal or to curl, but curl-minimal works for all Kolla container uses - so probably it also is ok for all other uses (it just supports FTP/HTTP/HTTPS, not all the other protocols that full blown curl does).
Third option is to stick to distro default, but allow the user to specify he wants curl, and then remove curl-minimal ;-)
See https://fedoraproject.org/wiki/Changes/CurlMinimal_as_Default

hrm, we have [1] that pulls in the full curl for the yum-minimal elements, which I think would get 9-stream.

I wonder if it is a better idea to standardise by installing the full curl package?  

Would just installing "curl" at [2] get that working?

manila_tempest_tests/services/share/v2/j.message: I think this should not be modified. The version of the graduation of share replicas is what actually dictates whether we need to add the experimental headers to the request or not, so we should continue relying on the version of the graduation, as that has not changed. Otherwise, we will end up sending create requests with experimental headers in all requests done from API version 2.56 to 2.71. Share replica APIs are no longer experimental in that range of API versions.

Some issues here:

This test is a duplicate of the other tests; the method "_verify_create_replica" in this file always sets the share network if the version is above the "SHARE_REPLICA_SHARE_NET_PARAM_VERSION"; so we'd need to fix some things:

1) The skipUnless decorator doesn't make sense compared to the ddt inputs - i mean, constants.MIN_SHARE_REPLICATION_VERSION is going to be less than "2.72" - so no point testing this version with this test, so i'd suggest dropping that version.

ironic/conductor/manager.py.message:
Another thing to consider. In the case of the bug, the node may, or may not be in placement. The node could have been unprovisioned, or marked as retired, and removed from the active pool entirely. Nova-compute processes still have the node cached and may cause the placement record to be re-created temporarily until the next refresh occurs.

I think that would be kind of bad since that in essence is a race condition we don't have visibility into.

Additionally, It occurs to me, and I suggest you check with the nova developers, that maybe instead of deleting, we should be marking the resource as completely consumed and allow to be removed from the resource tracker/placement as nova-compute iterates through the nodes on the next pass.

That *should* prevent scheduling with resource classes/traits. If the older style of scheduling is in use, then the results are likely not working as expected nor desired from a nova point of view.

I think that marking deleted node as fully consumed is not a proper solution, it's more cheating on Nova) It's not a good relationship pattern)
I emphasize that the patch helps, but doesn't guarantee the solution.
If resource provider wasn't in-place or was re-created Ironic has nothing to do, Ironic did his best)

Nice change, it seems to be faster using this approach indeed. I have only one question, is there any kind of limitation in the amount of entries we can use in this 'in' clause in the Gnocchi's search API? is it unlimited? Thanks

We are shifting the paradigm here. Before this patch, to discover all scopes IDs, one would go through all of Gnocchi resources. However, normally, one will use as the scope attribute the account ID, project ID, or some other identifier that represents the user/owner of resources.

If we consider a cloud with 1.000.000 different resources registered in Gnocchi (VMs, volumes, IPs, VPN, and so on), the current approach will list all of the 1.000.000 resources to discover all scope IDs. On the other hand, with the proposed solution here, we use the ``search`` method in Gnocchi, and search for all resources where the scope attribute is not in the already found scopes. For the first request, we do not use filter; however, for the subsequent ones, we use the already discovered scopes, and so on. This reduces drastically the number of calls to Gnocchi. Moreover, even for clouds where the number of resources is close to 1.000.000+, the numbers of project IDs, accounts or other identifier will probably be in the 1.000 (probably less), which reduces the number of calls to Gnocchi by 10 folds already.


In the worst case scenario if somebody uses scope attribute as resource ID, then this new approach will be as fast as the previous code. On the other hand, if somebody uses user_id or project_id as the scope attribute, this new method tends to be way faster.

  domain, self.results['changed'] = ....

Assigning one half of self.results in one line and the other half of self.results in another line breaks symmetry. Defining code branch of an if clause without the code branch for 'else' breaks symmetry. Combining both makes it harder to understand/grasp whats going on.

playbooks/tox/pre-molecule.yaml.message:
Is ok, podman no longer does that in recent versions. If it would have done it it would have caused an installation error, especially as podman is installed after docker.

There are other reasons why we may need both, some projects may have some scenarios with one and some scenarios with another and they may a lot of time to migrate all (not to mention the not very unlikely case when they may discover they cannot migrate one or more scenarios due to bugs or missing features of the new driver).

I was thinking about the same thing yesterday, to allow job to specify which ones to install or not but is not directly possible now, we may need a new role in zuul_roles for that. Also the idea of creating a new set of base jobs does not seem to scale well, we already have probably too many jobs in zuul.

If we would have a "required_roles" variable to pass to the job and mention which roles we want, zuul could loop over and include all these roles. That could prove useful for avoiding creation of extra jobs or having to create extra pre-run playbooks for including roles that are not mentioned in original job definition. Still, that would be outside the scope of this change.

I'm not a fan of installing both, in some cases I've seen package conflicts on centos-8-stream.

What about doing:

    - name: Install container runtime
      include_role:
        name: "ensure-{{ (container_command == 'docker') | ternary('docker', 'podman') }}"

Then we can install depending on the container_command, which is how our container / buildset jobs work.

manila_tempest_tests/tests/api/test_shar.message:
Thanks for the detailed explanation, Goutham. 
We're going to work on this change and provide a new patch set.

> But, I chose to use admin basically because it was already being used in the test (lines 56 and 65).


yes - these are specifically "admin-only" actions - i.e., listing pools and updating share type extra specs requires admin privileges.. 

> so I wondered if the developer mixed the names of the clients during the implementation.

I think so too; the way these credentials work is explained here: https://docs.openstack.org/tempest/latest/write_tests.html#allocating-credentials
In our tests, we request tempest to set aside three users from three separate projects: ('primary', 'alt', 'admin') in the "BaseSharesMixedTest" class [1]. 

- The "primary" project will have a regular user called "primary", assigned a "member" role. 
- The "alt" project will have a regular user called "alt", with a "member" role assigned to the user. 
- The "admin" project will have an user called "admin", with the "admin" role. So 

as you can imagine, the "admin" user has access to project resources within "primary", "alt" and "admin" projects because of their role. The "primary" user and "alt" user can only operate within their assigned projects. 

When doing tests like this, we should test with the "primary" user so that we can test the RBAC alongside the API schema and behavior. The "alt" user can be used when we want to test isolation between projects - i.e., the "alt" user cannot access "primary's" resources. 

You're right in fixing this up to not use the alt user - we don't need it here. We're not testing isolation; but, please use the "primary" user (cls.shares_v2_client) instead of the "admin_shares_v2_client" because the operation you're performing - getting a share network doesn't need admin privileges. 


[1] https://github.com/openstack/manila-tempest-plugin/blob/5e559df86912a5dcc8a071a64cac65e55189695a/manila_tempest_tests/tests/api/base.py#L1251

I don't know much about these users and roles, so I might be wrong. 

But, I chose to use admin basically because it was already being used in the test (lines 56 and 65).

Also, alt_shares_v2_client and admin_shares_v2_client share networks seems to be configured in the same place [1] when multitenancy is enabled, so I wondered if the developer mixed the names of the clients during the implementation.

I didn't try to use shares_v2_client. Do you think we should try that?

[1] https://github.com/openstack/manila-tempest-plugin/blob/5e559df86912a5dcc8a071a64cac65e55189695a/manila_tempest_tests/tests/api/base.py#L1290

One wrinkle here is around PVCs - zuul-scheduler STS and the stateful sets associated with the database + zookeeper will also have to be bumped.  I'm thinking that (3) might be the best option because it provides a natural breakover point. 

Admittedly, I'm not 100% certain of how to deal with ZooKeeper or MySQL here because this would implicitly require a data migration between ZK/MySQL instances and the actual internals of these things is opaque to the operator itself. Thoughts?

As far as I know, nothing would change with any underlying instance itself *until* one of the config pieces change.  The startup code doesn't appear to trigger any configuration updates in the underlying setup *as of this change*. 

Going forward, users will likely want to re-name the underlying resources that are created such that they capture the extended name in lieu of the current non-distinct naming.
Er, sorry for the dupes.

I think those kinds of changes are expected often enough that a user could be pretty quickly surprised by suddenly having an extra Zuul.  So I think we need to account for that somehow.

Some ideas (alternatives; in order of preference):

1) Have the operator perform the migration itself.
2) A release note with a migration script users can run, along with a major version number bump of the operator itself.
3) A CRD API version bump (and naturally an operator major version bump as well).

swift/container/sharder.py.message: when would it not be None?!

first iteration of the loop it is still None, because we wanted to have the 

  if not objs:
       break
       
before calling dest_shard_ranges
looks like deleted objects are yielded before undeleted

added some tests in patchset 2 that illustrate, but it's undeleted first:

  for include_deleted in (False, True)

i don't get this break when we don't have enough ...

should it compare to batch_size?  maybe just an if objects: else?

maybe your comment was before I fixed this? 

I think if objects ... else will result in extra wasted lookups for no objects when the last lookup gave us less than batch_size

seems a little weird, but the existing signature didn't change

and i guess why pass a callable instead of the result-value-itself unless you're trying to defer/avoid calling it

we are trying to defer calling dest_shard_ranges

The current implementation of yield_objects_to_shard_range iters over the source shard range in an outer loop, and inside it iters over dest_shard_ranges, and so dest_shard_ranges is never called if the source has no objects, BUT that implementation is what caused the original bug whereby we might not go back for deleted objects.

Here, I turn it on its head and iter over dest_shard_ranges, and for each of them iter over the relevant part of the src until we have deleted and deleted, then move on to the next dest. But, that means I need a pre-flight check to make sure it is worth calling dest_shard_ranges to start the outer iteration.
i do like the explict iteratoin of the dest shard ranges - where we yield ALL objects/rows that belong to each.
the significance of returning None instead of the synthasized sub-src_range is not obvious from this diff

we never yield anything to do with the source range

Yielding None indicates that there is no dest in which to place objects found in the source. Based on getting a None back, the caller records how many unplaced objects there are and marks the attempt to move misplaced objects as a failure.

We could not bother even yielding objects when there is no dest shard range - they're not going anywhere - but currently we do so that we can count and report unplaced.

this seems like it's been totally re-written... did we "fix" anything else besides the slow query?

I think I'd need a picture of src/dest range boundary alignment to understand why we have 3 different yield_object calls in this function - i assume it has something to do with gaps or duplicate ranges in dest and tests would explain it if I tried removing some of these blocks?

I reverted yield_objects to pretty much how it was pre Ie8404f0c7e84d3916f0e0fa62afc54f1f43a4d06 

I've then re-written yield_objects_to_shard_range to fix the bug that Ie8404f0c7e84d3916f0e0fa62afc54f1f43a4d06 fixed (which was that tombstones were often not yielded)

I added test_yield_objects_to_shard_range in patchset 2 which may help illustrate

heat/engine/service.py.message:
Environment files are allowed to contain keys that don't correspond to a parameter in the template. This code will currently crash in that case (which suggests we should add a test for it).

Also, keys may correspond to parameters that are defined in _nested_ templates - if those are marked 'hidden' then that wouldn't be respected here either. I _think_ you can fix this by replacing param_schemata() with all_param_schemata().

Sorry, my fault, I was mixing up two separate sections: parameters, and parameter_defaults.
parameters keys are required to be defined in the root template
paramater_defaults keys are not, and may in fact be referenced only in a nested template.

So this patch is fine for parameters.
The same issue exists for parameter_defaults, and you'd have to go searching through all nested templates (perhaps using tmpl.all_param_schemata()) to check for a definition that might have the 'hidden' flag.

Sorry, I'm a newbie on this project but working hard to contribute to it.
I have surveyed your comments and tried to reproduce the issue.
Here are some investigations:
1. Environment files are allowed to contain keys that don't correspond to a parameter in the template
I created an env yaml which contains a key in [parameters] section that doesn't show up in the template's parameter.
When I use it to create a stack, it will fail because the parameter doesn't define in the template.
It seems like Parameters::validate() will validate if all user-provided parameters are actually defined in the template.

2. Keys may correspond to parameters that are defined in _nested_ templates
I defined parameters that were marked as hidden in a template (resource.yaml) and use a different template (app.yaml) to use it as resources.
To pass user-provided parameters to resource.yaml, app.yaml also needs to define parameters.
I have tested the 'stack show' command and it also shows plain text if parameters don't mark as hidden in app.yaml.

I think there may have some scenarios that I don't consider.
Could you please give me some hints about it?

ok so this is for spice.

we do not support direct conenction to the vm via s spic clent 
we only support connecting via the spice proxy

is audio supported in that configuration vai horizon?

by the way if VNC and RDP are installed in the guest they usaly can enable audio for the vdi usecase without changed to the vm. windows support a seperate software emulated audio service that can be enabeld in the OS. linux can also provide emulated audio devices but those will not be accable to qemu.

do you need to add these as image properties to glance? 
https://docs.openstack.org/glance/latest/admin/useful-image-properties.html

need no but should

they should also be added to https://opendev.org/openstack/glance/src/branch/master/etc/metadefs/compute-libvirt-image.json

the glance metadefs is the programatic api to discover what image properties are valid. this is used by heat and horizon to generate teh dialogs used to add image properties to images.
Do we need to change anything on our novncproxy service to make this work?

no curerntly audio is not supported when using vnc, it is for spice but our proxy just converts the tcp socket into a websocket so that it cna be used form a web client. this will just enable vms to have a virtualised audion device.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
Some general thoughts:

I should note that it is an explicit goal to be able to install the operator with only a handful of kubectl apply commands.  For a nearby example of another operator that is similarly simple to install, we can look at the Percona operator: https://docs.percona.com/percona-operator-for-mysql/pxc/kubernetes.html

That's more or less what our static instructions should look like too.  And yes, they have a helm chart too.  :)

I think adding a helm chart could be useful for the reasons you describe.  I just want to ensure that we continue to treat the static use case as first-class.
Ack

Would it be possible to generate the static files from helm in order to reduce duplication?

A way I could imagine that working is that we continue to check both into git, but we have a script that performs the helm -> static transform, and we have a zuul job that does the same thing to ensure that the contents in git are correct (we do similar things in the zuul-jobs repo for auto-genrated files).
Yes, this should be fairly easy to do using the `helm template` command.  I have a commit later in my stack to remove the static templates, but I can revise it to do this instead.

If this is so, then we should be able to change the static files too.

There are two versions of the static rbac configuration: one is a cluster-admin, and the other is not.  For users who don't want the built-in operator management, the second can be used.

If we're going to have a helm chart, it should operate in the same way and do the same thing as the static files.  I'm especially concerned about ending up with even more variations of how rbac is configured.
Updated later commits in the stack

Unless you plan to turn zuul-operator into something like RedHat's operator LCM that doesn't seem like it'll work out super well, especially as other users of the PXC operator in the cluster might be broken by such an approach.

Sure: with one caveat - I think we should provide a mechanism to disable this auto-install functionality in the operator in case of user misconfig.  This can be a pain to clean up from if that's not what you actually desired.

If the user is assuming the PXC operator is installed then there's 3 avenues that can work:

1. Generate the static templates from the Helm chart and add that to the list of things to kubectl apply -f 
2. Use the helm chart with the nested charts for PXC and cert-manager
3. What we're doing right now

Both (1) and (2) provide an easy way for the user to transparently manage the upgrade and are trivial to provide

(3) is pretty opaque and will require a non-trivial work to deal with (eg: what happens when the operator upgrade fails? how do you surface that to the end user? etc).  This also seems like an atypical way for an operator to function and is akin to what LCM provides

As to the non-admin RBAC - we can regenerate that from the helm chart.  As it stands right now, the actual roles granted by the non-admin are not sufficient for proper function.

Another thing to consider: upgrades.

If the operator is used in batteries-included mode (i.e., it internally deploys the percona operator) then we would expect it to be able to upgrade the percona operator in the future.  We don't have any code to do that right now, but it is a possibility that was anticipated, and the current scheme supports it.

If we move the pxc operator into a pre-install step, how will the zuul operator handle pxc operator upgrades?
I'd have to look into whether we do anything with credentials or similar when configuring the other operators, but if not, I think we could consider moving those out.

In fact, both versions of the rbac.yaml bind to the cluster-admin role, not to the role that is created in the template.

As in the previous comment, we can generate the static files from the helm chart pretty easily which should ensure that these things match up.

It seems like the built in operator management would get triggered exactly once.  Is there a reason why it wouldn't just be better to have static templates for this as well?

Okay, here's the way I think we should view this from a high level:

* The helm chart should allow users to deploy the operator as written.  It should not drive change to the operator.

In particular, I think that affects things like the RBAC discussion.  If there's a problem with the rbac config, that should be addressed on its own.  The helm chart should install exactly the same manifests as the statically generated ones.

* Installation via static manifests should continue to be first-class.  Helm should not be required for the operator, and as described above, should not do anything different.

* The operator currently installs PXC if the user doesn't supply a database.  We should maintain that, and maintain the potential to upgrade the internal PXC in the future.  Anyone that doesn't want that functionality can supply a dburi (whether that's via a static manifest or as input to the helm chart).

In practice, I think those principals suggest the best course is to:

1) Address any RBAC issues first on their own.
2) Generate the static manifests from helm, along with a job to generate+verify output.
3) Add helm charts, along with an additional functional test job to run the operator using helm.
That sounds reasonable.

The spec in the developer docs coveres this pretty well I think.  If the user is asking Zuul to deploy the PXC operator, there probably aren't any other users, and the zuul operator should manage it and upgrades.  That probably means that the PXC handling internal to the operator should remain, unless there's a good way to handle that otherwise.

Regarding the rbac, if the non-admin rbac file is binding to the admin role, that's probably an error.

Assume the person reading this doesn't know what's going on.  This would be clearer as:

We need to support upgrading from a CentOS-based system to a Debian-based system.  Debian uses OSTree which means that /usr is read-only.  During the upgrade of a multi-node system there is an issue where the kube-controller-manager-controller-1 pod (created on the CentOS system) is trying to write to /usr/libexec which is not valid on the upgraded node running Debian.

puppet-manifests/src/modules/platform/ma.message:
This will change the static pod on the node running this manifest, but we probably also want to update the kubeadm configmap (in the kube-system namespace) to make the change permanent.

Otherwise, I suspect things will break when we upgrade K8s because the static manifest files will be regenerated from the kubeadm configmap as part of the K8s upgrade.

As discussed in IM, we will have different CR for k8s upgrade configmap change with new plugin directory in order to make it permanent. 

We need this CR (for k8s running during platform upgrade) and a different CR (for permanently change during k8s upgrade).
Why is this needed?  On a downgrade wouldn't we be reinstalling the node with 21.12?

There are two scenarios for downgrade.
1. Only controller 1 is upgraded before downgrade. In this case, controller 1 will use "kubeadm join" to join the k8s cluster on controller 0. The k8s configurations are from controller 0 so this code change is useless as the old plugin directory is used in controller 0. 
2. Both controllers are upgraded before downgrade. In this case, since the new plugin directory is used before downgrade, the new plugin directory is used after downgrade is complete *if* we don't change it back to old plugin directory. 

I will remove this code for now to make this CR only for upgrade. I will have a different CR for downgrade.
Should probably mention in the code comment here that there will be a separate change to update the kubeadm-config configmap.

This will affect the written static manifest, but for upgrades we will also need to update the kubeadm-config configmap (in the kube-system namespace) otherwise we'll need to keep the above code around for every subsequent version.

nova/virt/node.py.message: it is probably fine but we are leaking open file description here.

OK, I'm blindly applied the "always explicitly handle the close of a file descriptor" rule. 

I think in this case we rely on the garbage collector to collect file descriptor and during that collection the fd is closed. 

As far as I know cpython has a refcount based primary garbage collector and a secondary collector for cyclic references. Here we can be sure that the temporary fd will not have a cyclic ref and only goes from refcount 1 to 0 during the open().read() line. So cpython will close this after read() (or after the exception raised by the read() is handled up somewhere in the stack that can be arbitrary far from this line).

As far as I know pypy does not have a refcount based collector just a generational one. So under pypy the open().read() line will not close the fd immediately it will be closed when the gc run, and that gc probably run only at memory pressure. 

```
def read():
    open("a.txt").read(40)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    while True:
        read()
```

This code will have at most 1 open fd to a.txt under cpython and will have around 5k - 15k open fd to a.txt under pypy on my machine.

So as I said above it is probably fine as is. But we rely on the deep internal of the python interpreter *implementation* that can change. So the general rule of always explicitly close an open file has a power too as it would make the two python interpreters execute the same code with the same external resource constraints.

I see, but is that optimized then? I mean, you are filtering using between and then using <= end again to maintain the result as it was before. Is this going to be faster?

Oh, Seeing the code, now I understood what you meant in optimizing the query. 

What you described in the Patch description does not comply with what you did, because simply changing a clause from x >= y and x <= z to x between y and z does not have any runtime impact.

What you want to do (at least it was what I understood), is increasing the filtering for the begin clause, so as we are validating that the begin must be always < than end, it means that if we have registries with the begin date greater than the required end date, these registries must be ignored before we apply the end date filtering, which means lots of less data to process for very past periods.

So I would only suggest you to update the Patch description to fit better with your optimization.

Looking at get_faults API again... 
resp = fm_core.get_by_eid(entity_instance_id)

The V1 API itself doesn't make any distinction between False, None returned from get_by_eid function. For all these cases the value returned by get_faults is None. We don't know how to distinguish between an actual error and no alarm found.
There will be retries even if no alarm was found without any error.

We can't add retries the way fm_api behaves now. We need to change the fm_api API.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
fm_api is used throughout conductor, we would need to convert all those places to use retries in the end. Or create an API that uses retries in fm_api then point conductor to use that.
We may need another launchpad to track that work, in case we don't use the same one as this commit..
I'm switching approaches to just clearing the alarms in upgrade script, leaving the fm_api refactor for another moment (since is a bigger change).

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/conductor/ku.message:
1) there will be retries even if list is empty

>>> if []:
...   print('A')
... 
# 'A' not printed

------------
2) besides 1, this only retries if get_faults failed, but clear_fault can also fail

---------
Looking into fm code I believe when get_faults and clear_fault return None is when the retries should be attempted for both API calls individually.
_clear_app_alarm is used in several places, retry mechanism should be implemented inside the function
Done. I originally put the retries outside because the method is used in some points just as a confirmation, but the cost added really is negligible.
If there are no alarms(and no API errors) we would still hit the else branch. This  fills the log without any value.
Suggestion: you can add the default parameter "app_alarms=None" in this method, so it can be passed when already available, like in line 215.

This method is used several times in this file. The previous implementation was something like "if there is an alarm, then clean it", but it didn't consider the case when there is no alarm as an error. An example is at line 418 (or 398 in the previous version):

  # In case there is an existing alarm for previous remove failure
  self._clear_app_alarm(app.name)

But in this new implementation, when "self._get_app_alarms(app_name)" returns nothing, it logs error at the end of the method. I think the right behavior is to exit this method when there is no alarm, with no error log.

I will move the error in the last line of _clear_app_alarm to only log after the retries of _fm_api.clear_fault. However, I think we should maintain the logs for error from _get_app_alarms, which means that we still will have an error log in the scenario where _clear_app_alarm is called but there isn't an alarm raised.

With the implementation in FaultAPIs, we cannot differentiate between the no alarms scenario or the issue scenario.

    def get_faults(self, entity_instance_id):
        with fm_api_lock:
            try:
                resp = fm_core.get_by_eid(entity_instance_id)
                if resp:
                    data = []
                    for i in resp:
                        data.append(self._str_to_alarm(i))
                    return data
            except (RuntimeError, SystemError, TypeError):
                pass
            return None

It only returns 'None' (either on error or because there isn't an alarm) or a list with at least one alarm.

Switching for FaultAPIsv2 on the whole code or changing the FaultAPIs would be a riskier change, so I think we are stuck with retry based on the None return (accepting the cost if there aren't alarms) or not retry at all and seek another solution. The same goes for the call to 'clear_fault' with a False return.

We of course could retry but not log, but the bigger part of the work to investigate this issue was to trace it to this code due to the lack of logs.

_____________________________________

I'm switching approaches to just clearing the alarms in upgrade script, leaving the fm_api refactor for another moment (since is a bigger change).

This is to handle the error scenario if the volume type in the deployment does not contain extra spec 'fungible:vol_type'. If extra spec contain a value for key 'fungible:vol_type', then that will be used as the volume type. Otherwise default value of VOL_TYPE_BLK_EC will be used.

plugins/module_utils/resource.py.message: Should we return "changed=True" in check_mode? Or shall we always return "changed=False"?
Ansible's own modules such as apt, file, lineinfile, systemd_service and group all return a proper changed value when running in check_mode.

I guess we should add possibility here and everywhere else to override desired status/failures/status. In most of cases we have them standardized, but iirc there were some funny exceptions (servers and volume attachments may be tricky).
Agree. Let me add a TODO for this improvement as future work.

In principle yes. Actually at the very beginning I was not expecting you would switch all modules to the SM internals therefore was more or less evaluating the module in the scope of a standalone module. But I agree, this is better to be overridden by individual modules.

Perhaps a better solution is to create a subclass of StateMachine and override specific functions such as _create(), _update() or _delete() as shown in [1],[2],[3],[4]. This approach saves us from code bloat in the resource module. 

Additional module parameters for customizing 'status' and 'attribute' in wait_for_status() would require a knowing openstacksdk internals and thus only useful for a small circle of people who could just fix existing modules instead ;)

playbookconfig/src/playbooks/roles/commo.message: What's the reason for switching back to older version of cert manager images?

When we restore etcd and raise kubernetes master in side n+2, cert-manager pods will raise with the images they had in side n (tag v0.15.0), but during the "download images" step the downloaded images would be the ones in this file (tag v1.7.1) and as a consequence, cert-manager pods won't run because they are using the old tags, that were not downloaded; this causes playbook failure later on:

Step: Apply kubernetes yaml to create cert-manager clusterissuer and certificates
Error: Internal error occurred: failed calling webhook "webhook.cert-manager.io"

Switching back to older tags is one approach, but please advise if you think there is a better approach.
Why does this particular image need to stay at v1.7.1 while the rest have to be 0.15.0?

It was introduced later with commit https://review.opendev.org/c/starlingx/ansible-playbooks/+/841789 and does not exist with tag v0.15.0 (i.e. docker pull quay.io/jetstack/cert-manager-ctl:v0.15.0 will return "not found")

How about we implement a dnsmasq based BaseDHCP? There could be a dnsmasq.d enabled with dhcp-optsdir and per-node files written which match on the MAC, tag with the node UUID, then do a dhcp-boot specific to the boot interface. Then send dnsmasq a SIGHUP.

yeah, (solution 1) there's a way to assign priorities to each column, so lower-prio columns would be "hidden" if they don't fit with the box (we can observe this behavior in the instance creation form)
But it means that users with Firefox 103.0.2 would never see those columns

(solution 2) we can also display only a part of the UUIDs

(solution 3) Another way would be to remove the UUIDs of the subnets and networks (note that solution 1 would have the same impact on user)

table-responsive is a workaround but it also hides an important column

I would rather hide the uuids (it seems that most of the forms don't show UUIDs - cf instance create)
I just found out that Chrome does the same if the page is less than 992 pixels wide. It's probably not a critical issue, but also not ideal.

Another solution I just found that also works for Firefox is to use div class="table-responsive" 

https://getbootstrap.com/docs/4.0/content/tables/#responsive-tables

I think that would be a good solution.

https://i.imgur.com/QZ5xxNV.png

In Chrome, if the page width is less than 768px it gets displayed correctly too because it hides the nagivation bar on the left. This is probably the "xs" class. So there this issue exists only within 767px < page_width < 992 px, which seems to be the "sm" size. In Firefox this happens with all screen widths.

I don't think we need to hide information. Maybe we can make the widths of the Subnet Id and Network Id smaller?
well, now we display a shortened UUID and there's a tooltip that displays the full UUID
I think this is good enough.

This commit itself looks good, but I see a point to be clean up around server_*_console().

Looking at the codes which refer to get_mks_console, all server_*_console() variants are called with the same arguments [1][2]. Thus, all of these variants should have the same arguments. I think other server_*_console() should be same.
I will send a follow-up cleanup.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/horizon/src/commit/193320f64ebbe7501a93e053387247ce95b399e5/openstack_dashboard/dashboards/project/instances/console.py#L27-L31
[2] https://opendev.org/openstack/horizon/src/commit/193320f64ebbe7501a93e053387247ce95b399e5/openstack_dashboard/api/rest/nova.py#L249-L253

> Looking at the codes which refer to get_mks_console, all server_*_console() variants are called with the same arguments [1][2]. Thus, all of these variants should have the same arguments. I think other server_*_console() should be same.
> I will send a follow-up cleanup.

For other server_*_console() variants, the corresponding novaclient methods accept "console_type" argument. I guess this is the reason that these methods have "console_type" argument regardless of that horizon does not provide a way to specify a console type even if there are multiple console types are available (for example, VNC accepts two types).

Considering this, I think there is no **strong** need to clean them up.

Thanks,

RamS ?

Which designer knows if there is a mechanism for specifying overrides in a yaml file for the restore playbook ?

The method for overrides used during restore is standard ansible for extra vars, "-e @path/to/file.yaml", which supports vault.

e.g. 
ansible-playbook /usr/share/ansible/stx-ansible/playbooks/restore_platform.yaml --ask-vault-pass -e "@path/to/overrides.yaml"
Examples are correct, but none show override_files_dir being used.
Correction:  The same "override_files_dir" is also available during restore.

This change needs to be micro-versioned; meaning that you will need to bump up the API microversion, and stop supplying the parameter only in the new micro-version. 

Here's an example of how that's done: https://github.com/openstack/manila/blob/6c47b193b07a96f7131b6241d6323387acd33979/manila/api/views/share_instance.py#L72-L76

Some documentation about bumping up the API microversion:
